IREL AND. In Mr.. Chateaubriands Speech,
relative to England and Portugal, there is a par
tlcular reference to the state OF Ireland, exhb
ting an angry conflict Of interest and opinion,
equally omnous to the welfare OF England in
case of hostilites, as that which Mr. Canning had
thought proper to speak OF As existing in the
bosom, and threatening the power OF the other
nations OF Europe. This retort was to have
been expected; but we did not think it, at the
moment Of perusal, so entirely justified by fact,
as twould appear to be from another speech de-
llvered almost simultaneously with it, and on the
same subject, in the unhappy country referred
to. The orator was Mr.. shicl, the celebrated
catholic barrlster, and his language is no doubt
that OF all his catholic brethren.


After calculating the probabilities of war, and
adopting the conclusion that it must take place
he says that, in the spirit Of dscontented fear
lessness he reoccs at it! that il is from calamity
alone, the Irish catholics can hope for an amelo
ration OF their condition; that they are like the
wretches confined in the hold of Il ship, who re-
Jolce at the roaring ofthe storm, because the
wave that carries the vessel upon the rock
tears their prison assunder, with nothing to loose
by destruction, and something to hope for in
the chance of preservation! He says that it is
an awful situation TO be in, where sentiment Of
desperate and disastrous exulaton is felt in
whatever portends calamity! .'We are like ne.
groes in slave ship" .As things stand at pres
ent, We are compelled to exclaim in the Ian.
guage ofthe fallen spirit, 'sEvil, be thou, our
good. It would, indeed, be absurd to question
that IT IS from the dlstresses of the empire that
our pest expectations must be derived Facts
bear us unhappily out in this most unfortunate
calculation. There never was a concession made
10 Ireland, which was not wrunr from disorder


and extorted out Of fear" 1t may be said that


havo eebn speaking the language Of violence.

IREL AND. In Mr.. Chateaubriands Speech,
relative to England and Portugal, there is a par
tlcular reference to the state OF Ireland, exhb
ting an angry conflict Of interest and opinion,
equally omnous to the welfare OF England in
case of hostilites, as that which Mr. Canning had
thought proper to speak OF As existing in the
bosom, and threatening the power OF the other
nations OF Europe. This retort was to have
been expected; but we did not think it, at the
moment Of perusal, so entirely justified by fact,
as twould appear to be from another speech de-
llvered almost simultaneously with it, and on the
same subject, in the unhappy country referred
to. The orator was Mr.. shicl, the celebrated
catholic barrlster, and his language is no doubt
that OF all his catholic brethren.


After calculating the probabilities of war, and
adopting the conclusion that it must take place
he says that, in the spirit Of dscontented fear
lessness he reoccs at it! that il is from calamity
alone, the Irish catholics can hope for an amelo
ration OF their condition; that they are like the
wretches confined in the hold of Il ship, who re-
Jolce at the roaring ofthe storm, because the
wave that carries the vessel upon the rock
tears their prison assunder, with nothing to loose
by destruction, and something to hope for in
the chance of preservation! He says that it is
an awful situation TO be in, where sentiment Of
desperate and disastrous exulaton is felt in
whatever portends calamity! .'We are like ne.
groes in slave ship" .As things stand at pres
ent, We are compelled to exclaim in the Ian.
guage ofthe fallen spirit, 'sEvil, be thou, our
good. It would, indeed, be absurd to question
that IT IS from the dlstresses of the empire that
our pest expectations must be derived Facts
bear us unhappily out in this most unfortunate
calculation. There never was a concession made
10 Ireland, which was not wrunr from disorder


and extorted out Of fear" 1t may be said that


havo eebn speaking the language Of violence.

TIE UNITED STATES AND GEORGIA.


The following Message was received from
the President ot the United States, BY the
hands Of his private Secretary


70 TIE Senatr aud House Of Representatives
Of he United STATES:


Washington, 5th February 1927.


! submit TO the consideration Of Congress,
letter from the Agent Of the Uni'ed States
With the Greek Indians, VINO invoked the
protection of the government o. the United
States, in defence ot the rights and territory
secured 10 that nation, by the treaty con
cluded at Washington, and ratified, on the
part Of the United States, on the 22d of A.
prl last.


The complaint set forth in this letter, that
Surveyors from Georgia have been employ
ed in surveying lands within the Indian ter
ritory, as secured by that treaty, is authsn.
,icated by information inolcially received
from other quarters and there is reason to
believe that one or more Of the Surveyors
have been arrested in their progress BY the
Indians Their forbearance and reliance
upon the good faith cf the United States.
Will, II Is hoped, avert scenes OF violence and
blood, which there is otherwise too much
cause to apprehend will result from thcse
proceedings.

BY the second, it is directed, that if any

be found within any of the United States, or
either OF their territorial districts, such of
fender may be there apprehended, and

within such State or District, and that it

and having lawful warrant, to aid aud assist
such mag gihtrate, officer. or other person
so authorized. i'll arresting such offender,
and committing him to safe custody for trial
according to law.


/ The first of these processes is adapted to

Over head frowned the front of the preci-

No one had ever dreamt of sealing il, and

not led her young into danger; and now that
the brush dwindled away into strag-
Cling shrubs, and the party stood on an en-
jnence above the stream, and forming part
of the stroth.

From Braza-By the arrival at n. York
Of the Brig Horatio. Capt. Hall, from Rio
ja1eiro, we learn that the Empress Of Bra
Ill died on the 10th Of December. The
Emperor was at Rio, Grand about the first
Of December, on his way to Mentevldeo,
with about eight thousand men-the squad
ron had gone round. Com. Brown had tax
en-, off Santos, Brazilian Corvette, Of %
guns; and it was reported, and generally
believed, he had an action with the Brazilian
frisate, the latter end of November, and
that the Amazon had been much injured
Brown was in corvette cruising on the Bra
zil'an coast.


The United States frigate Macedonian had
been in port some time. The Cyane SAT-
ed for the River Plata on the second Of De-
cember. The Boston sailed for Santos at the
same time.

From Kcy Uest-We learn from Can,
Johnson, Of the sloop Emcline. arrived on on
Saturday, from Key West, which place h.
LETT IL days since, that Com. Porter remain.
ed in that port with his frigate the I.S.rtsd
and an armed hermaphrodite brig. There.
maindcr Of his squadron, consisting OF two
brigs, had sailed to scour the coast Of Cuba
Two frigates and three brigs of the Spanish
blockading squadron renamed of the port
The Commodore was under no apprehen,
siens from the Spaniards, as, from the ma.
turc Of the port he can put to sea withou.
difficulty. He had despatched one Of his
prizes to Havana with $50 prisoners, being
the first intimation the Spaniards received
Of his situation. His squadron was we'll
manned, but had few officers. His nephew,
Capt. Charles Porter, was second in com
mand.
